messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Computational methods for finding bi-regular cages

Paper Abstract: Abstract An ({r,m};g)ùëüùëöùëî(\{r,m\};g)-graph is a (simple, undirected) graph of girth g‚â•3ùëî3g\geq 3 with vertices of degrees rùëür and mùëöm where 2‚â§r<m2ùëüùëö2\leq r<m . Given r,m,gùëüùëöùëîr,m,g, we seek the ({r,m};g)ùëüùëöùëî(\{r,m\};g)-graphs of minimum order, called ({r,m};g)ùëüùëöùëî(\{r,m\};g)-cages or bi-regular cages, whose order is denoted by n‚Äã({r,m};g)ùëõùëüùëöùëîn(\{r,m\};g). In this paper, we use computational methods for finding ({r,m};g)ùëüùëöùëî(\{r,m\};g)-graphs of small order. Firstly, we present an exhaustive generation algorithm, which leads to ‚Äì previously unknown ‚Äì exhaustive lists of ({r,m};g)ùëüùëöùëî(\{r,m\};g)-cages for 242424 different triples (r,m,g)ùëüùëöùëî(r,m,g). This also leads to the improvement of the lower bound of n‚Äã({4,5};7)ùëõ457n(\{4,5\};7) from 66 to 69. Secondly, we improve 494949 upper bounds of n‚Äã({r,m};g)ùëõùëüùëöùëîn(\{r,m\};g) based on constructions that start from rùëür-regular graphs. Lastly, we generalize a theorem by Aguilar, Araujo-Pardo and Berman [arXiv:2305.03290, 2023], leading to 737373 additional improved upper bounds.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Biregular cages of girth five",
        "Semicubic cages and small graphs of even girth from voltage graphs",
        "On the order of ({r,m};g)ùëüùëöùëî({r,m};g)-cages of even girth",
        "On bi-regular cages of even girth at least 8",
        "Constructions of bi-regular cages",
        "Regular and biregular planar cages",
        "Small bi-regular graphs of even girth",
        "Monotonicity of the order of (D;g)ùê∑ùëî(D;g)-cages",
        "Some properties of semiregular cages",
        "Cayley type graphs and cubic graphs of large girth",
        "Fast generation of cubic graphs",
        "The smallest cubic graphs of girth nine",
        "Graphs with prescribed degree sets and girth",
        "Small trivalent graphs of large girth",
        "Trivalent (cubic) symmetric graphs on up to 10000 vertices",
        "Trivalent symmetric graphs on up to 768 vertices",
        "Cubic semisymmetric graphs up to 10000 vertices",
        "House of Graphs 2.0: A database of interesting graphs and more",
        "(D;n)ùê∑ùëõ(D;n)-cages",
        "A small trivalent graph of girth 14",
        "Dynamic cage survey",
        "Biregular cages of odd girth",
        "Computational determination of (3,11) and (4,7) cages",
        "On biregular bipartite graphs of small excess",
        "Algebraic Graph Theory, volume 207",
        "Exhaustive generation of edge-girth-regular graphs",
        "Improved bounds for hypohamiltonian graphs",
        "On cages with given degree sets",
        "On vertex-girth-regular graphs: (non-)existence, bounds and enumeration",
        "Degree sets for graphs",
        "On girth-biregular graphs",
        "Fast backtracking principles applied to find new cages",
        "Practical graph isomorphism, II",
        "Fast generation of regular graphs and construction of cages",
        "Regular graphs",
        "Cubic vertex-transitive graphs on up to 1280 vertices",
        "Girth-regular graphs",
        "Current list for ‚Äúcensus of pentavalent arc-transitive graphs‚Äù",
        "A list of 4-valent 2-arc-transitive graphs and finite faithful amalgams of index (4, 2)",
        "Census of cubic Cayley graphs on up to 4094 vertices",
        "Census of 2-arc-transitive tetravalent graphs",
        "Census of arc-transitive tetravalent graphs",
        "A census of small connected cubic vertex-transitive graphs",
        "Bounding the order of the vertex-stabiliser in 3-valent vertex-transitive and 4-valent arc-transitive graphs",
        "Regular graphs with given girth and restricted circuits",
        "A family of cubical graphs",
        "Algoritmes voor het vinden van bireguliere grafen met gegeven taille",
        "Computational methods for finding bi-regular graphs of given girth",
        "Census of edge-transitive tetravalent graphs",
        "Recipes for edge-transitive tetravalent graphs",
        "The minimum number of vertices with girth 6 and degree set D={r,m}ùê∑ùëüùëöD={r,m}"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Computational methods for finding bi-regular cages, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
